questions.text: Out of total plasma osmotic pressure (oncotic pressure), the contribution of which of these is maximum?
questions.solution:
Colloid osmotic pressure also called oncotic pressure. About 80% of the total colloid osmotic pressure of the plasma results from the albumin, 20% from the globulins, and almost none from fibrinogen. Therefore, from the point of view of capillary and tissue fluid dynamics, it is mainly albumin that is important.



Refernce:- [Guyton; 14th ed; Pg. no. 199]

questions.text: During inspiration.
questions.solution: During inspiration due to contraction of diaphragm size of thoracic cavity is increased so air is suck inside, volume increased and pressure decreased

questions.text: Which of the following is reversal agent for methemoglobinemia?
questions.solution:
Methemoglobinemia = in Hb heme is presented as Fe+++ (ferric form), due to methemoglobinemia O2 carrying capacity of Hb is reduced. 

There are agents which can convert the Fe+++ to Fe++ (ferrous to ferric form)

Here in given question methylene blue (cofactor of NADPH reductase) can convert to methemoglobinemia to Hemoglobin, Glutathione is reducing agent it converts the Hb to methemoglobinemia.

questions.text: Which of the following is best explanation for this physiological fact "why the effects of the sympathetic division are more widespread than those of the parasympathetic division?"
questions.solution:
A. cell bodies is located in lateral horn of spinal cord for both divisions of ANS. - this is not the reason, so this is not the answer

B. Autonomic tone is continuous discharge from neurons of ANS that is present in both divisions so again this is not the answer

C. receptor for both the division present on target cell through which it exert the action but it is not the answer

D. Sympathetic divisions ganglia is present closest to spinal cord , therefore post ganglionic fibers are long and more diversion - this is correct answer

choices.text: Both neurons originate (have their cell body) in the CNS
Both neurons release ACh to signal their target cells
the pre-ganglionic neuron is short and post-ganglionic neuron is long
One neuron releases ACh to signal target cells and the other neuron releases norepinephrine

questions.text: Which of the following is true regarding the pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic neurons of the parasympathetic nervous system?
questions.solution:
A) Both neurons originate (have their cell body) in the CNS - False because cell bodies present in CNS for preganglionic neurons and in PNS for postganglionic neuron

B) Both neurons release ACh to signal their target cells - True pre-ganglionic and post-ganglionic neurons release ACh as neurotransmitters

C) Both neurons release neurotransmitters from varicosities - false the problem in the statement itself so consider as false

D)One neuron releases ACh to signal target cells and the other neuron releases norepinephrine false (this is true for SNS and not pSNS)

questions.text: Among the factors that influence breathing rate and depth, the most important are changing levels of carbon dioxide, oxygen, and hydrogen ion in the blood
questions.solution: Concentration of this substance sense by receptors, so these receptors first expose to arterial blood and that is why concentration of carbon dioxide, oxygen and hydrogen influence the rate and depth of respiration in arteries.

questions.text: Respiratory burst predominately occurs in which of the following cells?
questions.solution:
Respiratory burst predominately occurs in neutrophils (also observed in monocytes and macrophage) and causes the release of reactive oxygen species to kill pathogens.

Activation of NADPH oxidase is associated with a sharp increase in O2 uptake and metabolism in the neutrophil (the respiratory burst) and generation of O2-by the following reaction:

NADPH + H+ + 2O2+ → NADP+ + 2H+ + 2O2-

Reference:- [Ganong; 25th ed; Pg. no. 68]

questions.text:
70-year-old man was brought to OPD three months ago by his son, with a complaint that he had stopped shaving on left side of face for one week. He was also not using his left hand even though he had no weakness in that hand.
His BP was 170/110 mmHg and blood sugar was normal. He had no known medical illness. Examination revealed normal strength and sensations in his limbs and face. His vision was also normal. He could not perceive objects or people standing on his left side.
Which lobe of brain likely be affected?
questions.solution:
By case history and examination, Suspecting a disease in right side of brain and patient is suffering from left-sided hemineglect syndrome.

Hemispatial neglect, also known as unilateral neglect or hemineglect, is a sensory awareness problem caused by damage to the parietal lobe. In particular, it is associated with lesions on the posterior parietal cortex. The parietal lobe helps you process sensory information from the outside world.

Rapid diagnosis and prompt medical treatment can help in quick recovery

Monocytes after their life span in blood enter tissues and transform into tissue macrophages. They form mononuclear phagocyte system in various tissues

Blood - monocytes

Tissue -Macrophage



[Ref: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, pg 144-145, 160-162]

questions.text: Which of these type of abnormal red blood cells typically seen in lead and other metal poisoning?
questions.solution:
Basophilic Stippling means numerous basophilic granules (coarse and dark-blue granules) in red cells. This condition is called punctate basophilia. It is typically

seen in lead and other heavy metal poisoning. It also occurs in thalassemia, megaloblastic anemia, infections and liver disease.



Normal and abnormal red cells. (A) Normal red cell; (B) Microcyte; (C) Macrocyte; (D) Poikilocytes; (E) Anisocytes; (F) Spherocyte; (G) Elliptocyte; (H) Acanthocyte; (I) Drepanocyte (sickle cell); (J) Echinocyte (burr cell or crenated cell); (K) Dacryocyte; (L) Keratocyte; (M) Schistocytes (fragmented red cells); (N) Target cell; (O) Stomatocyte; (P) Basophilic stippling

[Ref: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, pg 85-86]

questions.text:
Experiment done on RBC for fragility asper details given below;Experiment done on RBC for fragility asper details given below;Experiment done on RBC for fragility asper details given below;

Suppose, if hemolysis starts from test tube No. 10, guess the condition from the following?
questions.solution:
Red blood cells, like other cells, shrink in solutions with an osmotic pressure greater than that of normal plasma. In solutions with a lower osmotic pressure, they swell, become spherical rather than disk-shaped, and eventually lose their hemoglobin (hemolysis). The hemoglobin of hemolyzed red cells dissolves in the plasma, coloring it red. A 0.9% sodium chloride solution is isotonic with plasma. When osmotic fragility is normal, red cells begin to hemolyze when suspended in 0.5% saline; 50% lysis occurs in 0.40-0.42% saline, and lysis is complete in 0.35% saline. In hereditary spherocytosis (congenital hemolytic icterus), the cells are spherocytic in normal plasma and hemolyze more readily than normal cells in hypotonic sodium chloride solutions



[Ref: Ganong physiology, 25th ed, pg 558-559]

questions.text: Itchy lesion started one week after tattooing as shown in image above -what could be the reason?
questions.solution:
Allergic contact Dermatitis - type IV hypersensitivity. Takes time to manifest as memory T cells are formed in sensitization phase.

Type I Reaction or Anaphylaxis: individual over-reacts to a sensitized allergen. Usually it occurs on re-exposure. But in highly sensitive individual, it occurs on first exposure

Type II Reaction or Cytotoxic Reaction: caused by IgG or IgM antibody, which is directed against antigen present on person’s red cells. Incompatible blood transfusions, hemolytic diseases of newborn and autoimmune hemolytic anemias are examples.

Type III Reaction or Immune Complex Disease: the antigen and antibodies form complexes that escape phagocytosis. These immune complexes are deposited on the basement membrane of the blood vessels. They activate complements and induce inflammation. Examples are glomerulonephritis, systemic lupus erythematosus (SLE) and rheumatoid arthritis.

Type IV Reaction or Cell Mediated Reaction or Delayed Hypersensitivity Reactions: mediated by macrophages that are activated by T cells. E.g. skin test for tuberculosis.

[Ref: G K Pal physiology, 2nd ed, pg 179]

questions.text: For 'x' skeletal muscle having duration of contraction period (CP) 0.04 sec. Now, if you want to develop tetanus in said muscle, what will be the minimal tetanizing frequency (MTF) for this muscle?
questions.solution:
MTF derived from the contraction period. Here CP is 0.04 sec.

Therefore MTF = 1/CP, = 1/0.04 = 100/4 = 25/sec.

So, if you want to tetanize this muscle, once should apply the stimulus to this muscle at the rate 25/sec. by this subsequent stimulus fall on the contraction period of the first one-muscles remain in state of contraction and tetanus is developed.

questions.text: Critical closing pressure is;
questions.solution:
When pressure falls below a critical level, called the critical closing pressure, flow ceases because the blood vessels are completely collapsed.

questions.text: This symbol of respiratory physiology to denotes.
questions.solution:
Symbols used in Respiratory Physiology:

A : Alveolar

a : Arterial (systemic)

aw : Airway

B : Barometric

C : Concentration or content in a liquid

c : Pulmonary capillary

D : Diffusion capacity

E : Expired

F : Fraction

f : Respiratory frequency

I : Inspired

P : Pressure

Q : Flow of blood

R : Resistance

S : Saturation of hemoglobin

V : Volume of gas

V : Rate of ventilation (volume of gas/unit time)

v : Venous (systemic)

V : Mixed systemic venous

[Ref: G K pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 885]

questions.text: In upright position, transpulmonary pressure at the base?
questions.solution:
Transpulmonary pressure (TPP) = IAP-IPP

transpulmonary pressure is always positive irrespective of phases of respiration but due to gravity it is minimum at the base and maximum at the apex. Size of alveoli is directly proportional to the TPP

questions.text:
Closing volume is always more than residual volume.
2. Lungs not only facilitates the respiration but also play a key role in blood production?
questions.solution:
CV>RV, The volume of gas in the lungs in excess of the residual volume at the time when small airways in the dependent portions of the lungs close during maximal exhalation. CV+RV=CC (closing capacity)

Statement 2:

This is newer function of lungs as hemopoietic organ So, both statements are true

[Ref: G K pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 885-908]

choices.text: Increased carbamino compounds are acidic and alter the pH.
CO2 bound to hemoglobin releases H+ and increases acidity.
Cl-shift in RBCs increases acidity in the plasma.
Increased CO2 in venous blood results in increased HCO3

questions.text: When comparing Arterial and venous blood in normal individual, it was noticed that the pH of the arterial blood was 7.40 while the pH of the venous blood was 7.36. How do CO2 differences in arterial versus venous blood account for these normal finding?
questions.solution: CO2 is higher in venous blood (extra 3.7 mL/dL). The action of carbonic anhydrase quickly converts CO2 and H2O into H2CO3, which can dissociate into HCO3− and H+. The net increase in CO2 naturally results in more acidic blood. The process is reversed when the blood passes through the lung and the additional CO2 is moved from the blood to the alveoli. While it is true that CO2 is released from metabolism that occurs in the tissue (A) and that additional carbamino groups (B) including with hemoglobin (C), none of these are acidic (eg, H+ generating) and thus can be ruled out. The Cl− shift (D) refers to the electroneutral exchange of HCO3− with Cl− across the RBC membrane; this does not alter H+ concentration and can be ruled out

questions.text: Mouth to mouth breathing is most effective method of artificial respiration, the reason is CO2.. What will be the PCO2 in expired air?
questions.solution:
Partial pressures of gases (mm Hg) in various parts of the respiratory system

questions.solution: Redistribution of blood flow

questions.text: Which of the following would not differ between a human on Earth and a human traveling in space?
questions.solution:
Human are homoeothermic so human body temperature remain constant irrespective of ambient temperature.



Effect of microgravity on body

questions.text: In a patient with cardiac output 5 liters/min and body surface area 1.7 m2 what will be the cardiac index?
questions.solution:
The cardiac index (CI) is an assessment of the cardiac output value based on the person’s body surface area (BSA).

CI=CO (l/min)/BSA (m2), CO=SV*HR

= 5/1.7, = 2.94 l/min/m2

Normal range of CI is 2.5 to 4 L/min/m2

questions.text: A 60-year-old man has a mean arterial blood pressure of 130 mm Hg, a heart rate of 78 beats/min, a right atrial pressure of 0 mm Hg, and a cardiac output of 3.5 L/min. He also has a pulse pressure of 35 mm Hg and a hematocrit of 40. What is the approximate total peripheral vascular resistance (TPR) in this man?
questions.solution:
TPR=MAP-CVP (mmHg)/CO (l/min)

= 130-0/3.5, = 37.14, = 37 mm Hg/l/min

questions.text: Which of the following segments of the circulatory system has the lowest velocity of blood flow?
questions.solution:
The velocity of blood flow (v) is inversely proportional to the vascular cross-sectional area (A): v = F/A

Thus, under resting conditions, the velocity averages about 33 cm/sec in the aorta but is only 1/1000 as rapid in the capillaries-about 0.3 mm/sec



[Ref: Guyton physiology;14th ed; Pg. no. 172]

questions.text: Physiological dead space is calculated by
questions.solution:
Dead space is defined as space within the airways that do not allow gas exchange with pulmonary capillary blood to occur

The ratio of dead space volume to tidal volume in normal health is 25 to 30%. Thus, normally 30% of the minute ventilation does not participate in gas exchange

Physiological dead space = anatomic dead space + alveolar dead space

Measurement of Dead Space by three methods:

  1. The Radford’s Formula - The anatomical dead space of an individual in milliliters is equal to his weight in pounds
  2. Single-Breath CO2 Technique - Bohr’s equation:


When, VD is the volume of dead space, VE is the volume of expired air, FAX and FEX represent the concentration of gas

in the alveolar air and mixed expired air respectively. As alveolar concentration of gas is same as arterial blood, Fax (concentration of substance in arterial blood) replaces FAX.

3. Single Breath Nitrogen Technique

[Ref: G K Pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 907-908]

questions.text: Which of the following is true at FRC?
questions.solution:
At FRC there will be no movement of air and thus Intrapulmonary Pressure = Atmospheric Pressure



Relaxation pressure-volume curve of lung, chest wall and respiratory system. Note that at functional residual capacity (FRC), the transmural pressure across the respiratory system is zero, and at total lung capacity (TLC), both lung and chest wall pressures are positive. (RV: Residual volume).

[Ref: G K Pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 894-896]

questions.text: All vital mechanisms are for maintaining constancy of internal environment'-This philosophy was first propounded by;
questions.solution:
• The ECF is also called the internal environment of the body, or the “milieu intérieu”, a term introduced by the great 19th-century French physiologist Claude Bernard
  • B Cannon - American Physiologist (1929): he gave the term “Homeostasis”
  • Hippocrates - father of medicine
  • William Harvey - father of circulation

questions.text: In steady state, value of which of the following is same in ICF & ECF?
questions.solution:
• Osmolarity (mOsmol/L)
  • Osmolality (mOsmol/Kg)
  • pH=H+ conc.

questions.text: The ability to detect two points simultaneously applied to the skin is based on which physiologic mechanism?
questions.solution:
Lateral inhibition is the phenomenon in which a neuron's response to a stimulus is inhibited by the excitation of a neighboring neuron. nerve signals to neighboring neurons are diminished

Lateral inhibition - sharpen and precise the sensation/perception, same priniciple applied in vision to enhancing image contrast, color discrimination, and light adaptation.

questions.text: Which molecules move from the endolymph into the stereocilia and depolarize the hair cell?
questions.solution:
Depolarization of hair cells due to the K+ ions.

Bending of cilia towards kinocilium opens K+ channels, through which Ca++ enters hair cells and produce depolarization. Bending of cilia away from kinocilium closes K+ channels, and prevents entry of Ca++ that produce hyperpolarization.



Stimulation and inhibition of hair cells. Note, bending of cilia towards kinocilium produces depolarization and bending of cilia away from kinocilium produces hyperpolarization

[Ref: G K Pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 1098]

questions.text: Following is the smallest cell in the CNS?
questions.solution: These all are supporting cells in CNS

questions.text: Increased in extracellular Na+ has following effect on RMP;
questions.solution: In resting condition, membrane is not permeable for Na ion. K ion is mainly responsible for the RMP.

questions.text: Movement of gases from nose to 16th generation airways occurs by
questions.solution:
Airways progressively branch 23 times (23 generations of airways). They are broadly divided into two categories: conducting airways that move air by convection into the gas exchange areas of lungs (conducting zone) and respiratory airways that participate in gas exchange (respiratory zone).

[Ref: G K Pal physiology;2nd ed; Pg. no. 882]

questions.text: What is the osmolarity of a solution containing 10 millimolar NaCl, 10 millimolar KCl, and 10 millimolar CaCl2 (in mOsm/L)?
questions.solution:
10 millimolar NaCl - (10 Na + 10 Cl)20 mOsm/L

10 millimolar KCl -(10 K + 10 Cl)20 mOsm/L

10 millimolar CaCl2- (10 Ca + 10*2=20 Cl)30 mOsm/L

Thus 20+20+30=70

questions.text: In normal adult human male, the total surface area of the respiratory membrane is about;
questions.solution:
Humans have 300 million alveoli, and the total area of the alveolar walls in contact with capillaries in both lungs is about 70 m2.

[Ref: Ganong physiology;25th ed; Pg. no. 623]

questions.text: Depagliflogin that inhibits the Glucose reabsorption in kidney;
questions.solution: By inhibiting SGLT2, dapagliflozin blocks reabsorption of filtered glucose in the kidney, increasing urinary glucose excretion and reducing blood glucose levels. Its mechanism of action is independent of pancreatic β cell function and modulation of insulin sensitivity.

questions.text: Coffee or Tea act as Diuretics by;
questions.solution: Evidence shows that caffeine acts on the kidneys by inhibiting sodium reabsorption in the proximal and distal tubules

questions.text: Metabolic Acidosis or Alkalosis is related to concentration of;
questions.solution:
Na - hyponatremia or hyponatremia (145 meq/l)

HCO3- Metabolic acidosis/alkalosis (24 meq/l)

PCO2 -Respiratory acidosis/alkalosis (40 mmHg)

pH- Acidosis/alkalosis (7.35-745)

K+ - hypokalemia/hyperkalemia (5 meq/l)

questions.text: The term 'Artificial Kidney' is applicable to;
questions.solution: There are two kinds of dialysis. In hemodialysis, blood is pumped out of your body to an artificial kidney machine, and returned to your body by tubes that connect you to the machine. In peritoneal dialysis, the inside lining of your own belly acts as a natural filter

questions.text: Which of the following techniques is used to study current flow across a single ion channel?
questions.solution: Patch-clamp is a technique to record ion current flow through a single protein channel

questions.text: Assuming a respiratory rate of 12 breaths/min, calculate the minute Ventilation
questions.solution:
RMV=RR*TV=12*500=6000 ml/min or 6 l/min

RMV also known as Pulmonary ventilation

One more important term being used (has more clinical relevance) is alveolar ventilation (AV) = [PV-DS]*RR

Lung volume increased and thoracic volume decreased
Lung volume decreased and thoracic volume increased
Lung volume decreased and thoracic volume decreased

questions.text: A 34-year-old man sustains a bullet wound to the chest that causes a pneumothorax. What best describes the changes in lung volume and thoracic volume in this man compared with normal
questions.solution:
Basic tendency of lung to collapse and basic tendency of chest wall is to expand. Under normal situation both are balance at one point (at FRC)

Here due to bullet injury plural space expose to atmosphere so there is no balance in lungs and chest wall so Lung volume decreased and thoracic volume increased

choices.text: Rt bronchus more wider and more parallel to trachea

questions.text: Infection/FB Common in Rt. Lung, because.
questions.solution:
• The right side of bronchus has more diameter
  • It is present in parallel with trachea.
  • Therefore, inhaled foreign bodies lodge easily in the right lung than the left.

Thus, infection of right lung is common than that of left lung

questions.text: RQ in brain tissue
questions.solution:
RQ=co2 production/o2 utilization = 200/250 = 0.8 (in most of the tissue)

Glucose is the major ultimate source of energy for the brain; under normal conditions, Glucose is taken up from the blood in large amounts, and the RQ (respiratory quotient; of cerebral tissue is 0.95-0.99 in normal individuals).

During strenuous exercise RQ is 2

After exercise RQ is 0.5

In severe acidosis RQ is >1

During secretion of gastric juice, the stomach has a negative R because it takes up more CO2 from the arterial blood than it puts into the venous blood.

[Ref: Ganong physiology;25th ed; Pg. no. 487-488, 607]

questions.text:
In peripheral smear examination following type of cells are present

This type of cells are due to deficiency of ?
questions.solution:
This cells is Neutrophil - hyper segmented

Hyper segmented neutrophil typically present is Vit B 12 deficiency or folate deficiency or both (megaloblastic anemia)

Iron deficiency anemia - microcytic hypochromic RBC & Poikilocytosis
